title: Endoglycosidase H (Endo H) digestion assay

source.description: PREPARE:
Make sure the lysis buffer (Table 1) is chilled.
Get samples and keep on dry ice.
Get a large box and fill to approximately 2/3 with wet ice for the ice/water slurry (see below).

Prepare lysis buffer MM: Add 100X protease inhibitor cocktail (“PiM”) as well as 100X phosphatase inhibitor cocktail I (“PP”) and II to the lysis buffer in a 1:100 ratio. Keep the lysis buffer MM
from this point onwards. The protease inhibitor cocktail can be briefly thawed using the
heat block. Keep at
before re-freezing.

Cool down ultracentrifuge to
. Set parameters: TLA-100 rotor,
,
,
; apply vacuum.
When ready, thaw samples on wet ice and add an appropriate volume of the lysis buffer MM as soon as the cell pellet is almost thawed.

source.body:
Can also be thawed briefly at but make sure that the cell pellet is not completely thawed when lysis buffer MM is added.
Lysis buffer MM volume: approximately - ; around 3x the volume of the cell pellet; better too little than too much.

source.description: Resuspend the cell pellet to a homogenous (!) solution by trituration and keep on wet ice.

source.body: Make sure the top of the Eppis is carefully labeled since side labels will likely disappear during a later incubation in the dry ice/EtOH slurry!.

source.description: Prepare the ice/water slurry: add cold water to approximately half of the height of the ice layer.

Incubate samples for
in the ice/water slurry.
In the meantime PREPARE the following:
Label ultracentrifuge tubes on the side. Use P200 tip holder as a rack for the ultracentrifuge tubes.

Prepare dry ice/EtOH slurry approximately
before the
incubation on the ice/water slurry is completed:

    Add dry ice until saturation (dry ice doesn’t resolve quickly anymore; temperature of
    has stabilized).

Put Eppis into a floating rack and immediately place them in the dry ice/EtOH slurry in order to snap freeze the samples; incubate for
.

source.body: Make sure that the lid does not touch the dry ice/EtOH slurry to prevent EtOH leaking into the Eppis; only cell lysate needs to be exposed to the dry ice/EtOH slurry. Incubation time of is minimum; can incubate longer.

source.description:
Directly transfer Eppis onto a heat block and incubate at
for exactly (!)
(no longer!).

Repeat the described freeze/thaw cycle once → two freeze/thaw cycles (
/
) in total.
Keep samples on wet ice afterwards.

Get TLA-100 rotor (Beckman Coulter) and keep on wet ice, including the lid. TLA-100 rotor usually kept in the
cold room.

Transfer the cell lysate from the Eppis into the labeled ultracentrifuge tubes (thickwall polycarbonate tubes) and place them in the TLA-100 rotor
; keep the empty Eppis for a later step in case the labeling is sufficient and hasn’t been removed by the EtOH.

Place TLA-100 rotor into the ultracentrifuge; make sure it’s correctly placed (!); re-apply vacuum, make sure that the parameters are set correctly (
for
at
) and start. The ultracentrifuge might take a while to start because it will have to re-establish the vacuum; make sure that the ultracentrifuge gets back to
.
During the ultracentrifugation PREPARE the following:
Get TLA-100 rotor and keep on wet ice.
Remove ultracentrifuge tubes and transfer the supernatant to a new, correctly labeled and chilled Eppi; keep Eppis on wet ice.
A small cell pellet should be visible; transfer to the appropriate old, correctly labeled Eppi and keep on dry ice.

source.body: This cell pellet can be re-used, e.g., to check for αSyn levels by Western blotting; in this case store cell pellet at and later resuspend in approximately of the appropriate lysis buffer for Western blotting.

source.description:
For the BCA test either add
of the cell lysate to
water or dilute
of the cell lysate in a 1:1 ratio with
water before adding
of the 1:2 dilution to
water; in the latter case don’t forget to change the dilution factor on the Endo H spreadsheet to 50!.

source.body: I got more accurate results with a dilution of 1:25.

source.description:
If the Endo H is proceeded with on another day, transfer the Eppis with the cell lysate directly onto dry ice and immediately store them at
(to reuse, thaw cell lysates on wet ice); if the Endo H is to be proceeded with on the same day, place Eppis on wet ice and store intermediately in the
cold room.

During the incubation for the BCA test at
for
roughly label 2 Eppis for each condition (→ +/- Endo H).

Thaw 10X glycoprotein denaturing buffer and 10X G5 buffer at
(don’t vortex denaturing buffer as this will create a lot of small bubbles!).

source.body: Fine to briefly keep them in the heat block if they are not thawed when needed in the steps below; make sure that these buffers are very well mixed before adding them to the reaction volume!.

source.description: After BCA test use Chee-Yeun’s Endo H spreadsheet to calculate the protein concentration.

PREPARE: thaw Endo H (stored at
) on wet ice.
From this point onwards all in duplicate (→ +/- Endo H):

Thaw sample buffer (“5X SB”, kept at -20°C; Table 2) and protein ladder at
.

In case +/- Endo H samples have been frozen down, thaw at
and briefly spin down.

Add
5X SB to each
rxn; briefly vortex and spin down; denature proteins at
for
; briefly spin down.

PREPARE Novex® 10% Tris-glycine gel with adapter. For 1 gel prepare
running buffer:
10X Tris-glycine-SDS running buffer (Boston BioProducts) +
diH2O.

source.body: No need to recycle running buffer.

source.description:
Load
of the protein ladder and the entire reaction volume of the +/- Endo H samples – first all -Endo H samples followed by all +Endo H samples.
Run the gel:

Wet electrophoretic transfer onto a PVDF membrane (Bio-Rad) with 10X Tris-glycine transfer buffer (Boston BioProducts):
diH2O +
10X Tris-glycine transfer buffer +
MeOH [20% (v/v)].
Continue with immunoblotting using the Odyssey infrared imaging system (LI-COR Biosciences).
Prepare a plate for the BCA test; each condition in triplicate.
Label Eppis and chill them on wet ice.
Get dry ice.

Refer to the spreadsheet for mixing an appropriate volume of the cell lysate (
-
protein) with diH2O for a total volume of
; from this point onwards samples can be kept at
.

Add
of the glycoprotein denaturing buffer for a total reaction volume of
.

Boil at
for
. In the meantime transfer the cell lysate stock to
.

source.body: Make sure that the lids of the Eppis are tightly closed!

source.description: Briefly vortex and spin down.

In the meantime PREPARE the +/- Endo MMs:
MM-1 (+ Endo H): (
Endo H +
10X G5 buffer)/rxn; can be kept at
.
MM-2 (- Endo H): (
diH2O +
10X G5 buffer)/rxn.
Spin down briefly.

Incubate at
for
(minimum incubation time).

Spin down samples briefly; add
of MM-1 or -2, briefly vortex and spin down.

Store samples at
or
if the gel is to be run on another day.

Run at 100 V first for
– until the running front is completely condensed by means of the stacking gel.

Then increase voltage to 120 V and set timer to
.
Run the gel until the 37 kDa protein ladder band is approximately
-
above the lower end of the gel cassette; check gel regularly after
; don’t run too far!!.

Prepare
transfer buffer and keep in
cold room; can be recycled 3-5x.

Transfer for
at 60 V and
or for
at 65 V in the case of two simultaneous transfers.

Rb anti-GCase1:500Gt anti-rb IgG, DyL 8001:5,000
Rb anti-nicastrin1:500
Ms anti-GAPDH1:3,000Gt anti-ms IgG, DyL 6801:10,000

description: This protocol details the endoglycosidase H (Endo H) digestion assay.
